I wanted write a quick message to you, my neighbors, my community, my countrymen and women.

I know these have been tough times for so many, kids are home, daily lives have been disrupted, some loved ones can’t be seen in person, elderly homes can’t be visited, most of us are yearning for community interaction.

We will get through this together, don’t let anyone tell you different! While the whole of our nation has not been called upon to sacrifice together in a long time, an undeterred, indomitable, and unbeatable spirit runs through our American bloodlines. 

And while the country has had this ugly and unpredictable virus forced upon us, most of the country is slowly rising to President Kennedy’s profound words of “Ask not what your country can do for you, but what you can do for your country”.

Our Hampton Roads community understands sacrifice. For two straight decades, when something has happened in the world, anywhere in the world, and mother freedom needed to be defended, it has been our men and women, a large part of the less than one percent of this nation who have run forward to the sound of the fight. They are who has picked up the slack and shouldered the nation’s burden of sacrifice and service, it is our neighbors who pitch in to help with the kids or the yard work or the coaching of sports teams.

There is a generation raised in adversity, tempered by recession and war, proud of our American heritage, unwilling to sit back and watch the decline and division of this nation, preserving its providential promise to free people. I’m betting on them.

Now, a weary community, commonwealth, and country will have to rise to the occasion, brush off comfort for hardship, whatever the cost, to win this war against this invisible foe, and win we shall. 

There are new frontlines. Every American, who has been given the privilege of his or her citizenship is part of a selective service for our nation. It makes me proud that our brave healthcare providers are risking their lives every hour of every day in this conflict. 

Countless folks are posting on social media, offering to help others, Truck drivers keep driving, shelf stockers keep stocking, cooks keep cooking, dishwashers keep washing, first responders never stop responding, manufactures are retooling to provide medical masks, distilleries are creating hand sanitizer.  Volunteers are feeding families, teachers are helping stressed parents make sure their children continue to learn. Americans are resilient. 

The blunt fact is that all of us have been affected. Indeed, there will be some fundamental changes in this nation, some of us will be more affected directly or indirectly, we must remember that staying calm is as contagious as being fearful. Our triumph over this foe must not be impeded by selfish leaders in Washington, it must not be impeded by those who seek political gain rather than fixing an issue, it must not be impeded by citizens who take more than they need at the expense of our neighbors. 

I know that our American soldiers, our American workers, and our American business owner will continue to pull together and rise to this challenge now facing our nation with dogged persistence, just as our forefathers always have and we will emerge from this period as free people who are stronger and ready to forge our bright future.  

Your humble servant, Scott Taylor

Let's address the elephant in the room. I get asked a variation of this question often:

"Kathleen, are you a Trump supporter?" or "Kathleen, how can you support someone like Donald Trump? He says such awful things. His mannerisms are crass. His tweets are below the dignity of the office of President. He isn’t Presidential. He’s an embarrassment."

I’ve heard it all.

At one time or another, I’ve thought it all.

And yet, here I am still supporting him and planning to vote for him for a second term.

When DJT came onto the scene, descending the escalator, I was immediately drawn to his candidacy. He didn’t act or talk like a politician. He wasn’t condescending in his speech. He was matter of fact. More than that, he was saying aloud things I’d thought to myself for years, and I found myself, over and over, saying “Yes! Exactly!” His message resonated with me. He was putting into words the frustration I’d been feeling with government for decades. And I wasn’t alone in my reaction to his message.

Although I’ve lived in Utah the past 35 years, I have many friends and family who live in other States - States that are primarily back East. For years, I’ve listened to them express frustration regarding their economies - the loss of industries, jobs, etc... I knew that people were feeling desperate, and that they’d not been the recipients of the “hope and change” they’d been promised the preceding 8 years under the Obama administration. They were tired of empty promises made from the mouths of polished smooth talking politicians.

How many times does one fall for empty promises before a new kind of candidate comes onto the scene and instantly gets their attention?

So suddenly, a non politician - a businessman - someone who wasn’t an ideologue - was running for President. He didn’t use big words. In fact, he used very small words because he’d learned early on as a businessman that success is instantly limited when you talk down to people.

How many politicians fall into the category of arrogance and condescension? Many - probably most, actually. People across this Nation were tired of it. I was tired of it.

Now, a basic speaking-level candidate was offering easily understood solutions to the economy - answers to jobs that had been lost. That message spoke very loudly to those without jobs and who'd been unable to put food on their tables at night. His message especially spoke to those whose entire industries had been obliterated through decades of losing jobs overseas or across our country’s borders. This unlikely candidate was talking about bringing back jobs, fair trade practices, eliminating unfair tariffs and promising to put America first, and Americans back to work.

How did the Left respond?

They called him a racist, a xenophobe, a nationalist and soon began the comparisons to Hitler. Next, they insulted and belittled this man’s supporters. They, too, were called names: racists, rednecks, uneducated, deplorables, etc...

It was ridiculous and the height of arrogance. Again.

He made promises that he’d protect religious freedom. He has. He said he’d secure our borders. He’s certainly tried to, but for some reason, the Left - the same Left that used to support secure borders and legal immigration - now opposes both.

Politics as usual. And who wins? Not Americans.

The campaign continued.

Did any of us ever think Trump was an angel, or worthy of ecclesiastical leadership? No. And that was before those awful comments aired on that TV program with Billy Bush. Was I offended? Absolutely. I was sick about it. It was indefensible.

So, what to do at that point? The messages of the other candidates didn’t resonate with me, and frankly, I didn’t think any of the other Republican candidates were electable. Plus, it was just more of the same ole, same ole, and I was beyond tired of that.

Did I think Hillary would defend religious liberty? No.
Did I think she’d put America first? No.
Did I think she’d bring back jobs? No.
Did I think she’d support our armed forces? No.
Did I think she’d champion our interests abroad? No, and especially not after Benghazi.
She’d already (before she was a candidate) dismissed women (like me) who had chosen to be stay at home mothers. She didn’t respect women like me. How could she ever represent a woman like me?
Did I expect her to protect the sanctity of life? No.
Did I expect her to appoint judges to the bench who would honor and respect the Constitution? No.

What about Evan McMullin? I don’t know anyone who took his candidacy seriously, and I wasn’t going to take my precious right to vote and treat it like a joke.

To me, the choice was clear: vote for the candidate who will promote, defend and honor the liberties this country was founded upon or risk turning the country over to just another smooth-talking politician whose motto was “Self before Country.”

No thank you. Been there, done that.

President Trump has kept his promises, and then some. He’s done things that many Republicans have often promised to do but didn’t:

He has defunded Planned Parenthood.
He officially recognized Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and moved our embassy there.
Unemployment is the lowest in 51 years.
African-American unemployment the lowest ever recorded.
$1 Trillion in corporate money has been brought back to our shores.

This, and much more, despite relentless attempts to overthrow the election results of 2016 - the ultimate act of political arrogance.

No, I won’t defend Donald Trump’s crass words or actions, but I will support him - everyday - as President because his policies have been great for America.
